Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Structural Architecture and Evolutionary Plate-Boundary Processes along the San Jacinto Fault Zone
Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding earthquake physics is a critical step on the road to forecasting the short-term behavior of faults with obvious consequences for hazard mitigation. This is a project whose goal is to examine the dynamics associated with earthquake rupture. The studies to be carried out will provide much more comprehensive constraints on the way that a major fault zone behaves. Specifically, the project will combine detailed imaging of the San Jacinto Fault (SJF) in Southern California using an array to characterize the fault zone in the subsurface. It will couple this with surface outcrop and mapping of the fault zone, paleoseismic analysis, GPS analysis of crustal deformation, and theoretical work on seismic propagation to understand how factors such as fault damage, juxtaposition of different rock types, and segmentation affect the behavior of the fault zone. The Principal Investigators bring together current ideas about the rupture process and outline an approach that may be able to provide a quantitative understanding of the evolution of fault zone structures and related deformation phenomena (seismicity, strain fields) in actively deforming regions. This approach requires a framework that accounts for faults with evolving geometrical and material properties, as well as time-dependent interactions between the seismogenic zone and underlying viscoelastic substrate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided support to develop improved quantitative understanding of earthquake and fault physics at a rapidly deforming plate boundary, by linking high-quality multi-disciplinary in-situ observations from the San Jacinto fault zone with theoretical analyses. The research involved conducting detailed observational studies of structural and earthquake source properties at various scales, as they relate to fault dynamics and the plate boundary tectonics in southern CA, developing advanced techniques to extract refined robust information from the data, and developing theoretical tools to interpret and integrate the results. Specific contributions included the following:

 

  (1) Seismic wavefield, structural imaging and earthquake locations: (i) Derivation of double-difference earthquake tomography for the region with detailed imaging of across-fault velocity contrasts, low velocity zones, and the surrounding structures. (ii) Analyses of scattering and spatio-temporal variations of seismic noise in the area, theoretical modeling of attenuation effects on noise correlation functions, and noise-based Rayleigh and Love waves tomographic imaging for the region that complement the earthquake tomography. (iii) Analyses of fault zone head waves, trapped waves and internal fault zone reflections for local high-resolution images. (iv) Monitoring temporal changes of seismic velocities with noise-correlation techniques. (v) Effects of across-fault velocity contrast and sedimentary basins on apparent vertical Moho offset across large faults, and estimates of the Moho structure in southern CA (vi) Algorithms for automatic detection of earthquakes and automatic phase picking of P and S direct waves along with fault zone head and trapped waves. (vii) Joint derivation of 3D earthquake locations and tomography in the San Jacinto fault region.

 

  (2) Earthquake source and ground motion: (i) Quantifying focal mechanism heterogeneity in different sections of the San Jacinto and other fault zones in CA. (ii) Derivation of Ground Motion Prediction Equations for the San Jacinto region and analyzing correlation of motion parameters and directivity with structural elements in different sections of the fault zone. (iii) Developing and using a generalized methodology for waveform inversions to obtain full earthquake source tensor properties, with a focus on isotropic components and uncertainty estimates.

 

  (3) Fault mechanics: (i) Using dynamic rupture simulations to establish quantitative connections between different types of ruptures, signatures of off-fault damage, secondary deformation structures near stepovers, and expected radiation. (ii) Analytical and numerical model results for non volcanic tremor as a critical-depinning on a frictional interface below the seismogenic zone. (iii) Developing theoretical bridges for dynamics of damaged solids and granular media that helps unifying various aspects of brittle rock deformation. (iv) Developing a model for observed signatures of shear heating in a section of the San Jacinto fault with a broad damage zone.
